Award.AwardTitle: Collective Dynamics of Mechanical Systems with Applications to Bridge Modeling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern pedestrian and suspension bridges and other large mechanical structures are designed using industry-standard packages, yet disastrous resonant vibrations are observed, necessitating multi-million dollar repairs. The main objective of this research project is to contribute to mathematical modeling of resonant vibrations caused by collective behavior of pedestrians or wind-induced coherent oscillations of load-bearing elements of bridges. This synergistic project aims to develop experimentally-validated nonlinear theory that will help engineers to estimate (i) the dynamical impact of pedestrian loads and (ii) a range of dangerous frequencies due to induced collective oscillations in a bridge's suspension/supporting systems. Such frequencies, which cannot be identified through the conventional linear calculations of natural frequencies, can lead to faulty, collapsing designs. Results from this research may lead to improved safety and economic benefits.

This project focuses on an area of nonlinear science entailing mathematical analysis and modeling of mechanical networks, including bidirectional interactions between walking pedestrians and lively bridges and wind-induced oscillations of load-bearing elements of bridges. The first part of this project seeks to develop bio-mechanically inspired models of pedestrians' responses to bridge motion and detailed, yet analytically tractable, models of crowd dynamics and phase-locking. This project also seeks to verify a hypothesis that the balance control of pedestrians based on the lateral position of foot placement can initiate bridge wobbling, without crowd synchronization. The second part of this project aims at better understanding the cause of dangerous vibrations and bridges collapsing as a result of wind-induced oscillations at a frequency different from the natural frequencies of a bridge. The interdisciplinary research utilizes methods from applied mathematics and engineering, including stability and bifurcation theory, piecewise smooth and stochastic dynamical systems, graph theory, classical mechanics, and bio-mechanics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: The funds have been used to make significant progress in the study of cooperative dynamics of mechanical oscillators, including bio-inspired models of walking pedestrians, models of suspension bridges, and mechanical rotators. The work performed under this grant resulted in seven published journal papers and two journal papers under review, one referered conference proceeding, two Springer book chapters, three published Ph.D. theses, and one 2016 Focus Issue of Chaos on cooperative dynamics of mechanical oscillators, co-organized and managed by the PI.

This grant developed experimentally-validated nonlinear theory that can help engineers estimate the role of pedestrians in the initial formation of a bridge formula in order to design robust bridges and avoid the range of dangerous frequencies that cannot be identified through conventional linear calculations. This grant also put forward rigorous mathematical insight into the cause of dangerous vibrations and bridges collapsing as a result of wind-induced oscillations at a frequency different from the natural frequencies of a bridge. These insights support the claim that wind-induced phase-locking of suspension/load-bearing elements can explain the shift of the resonant frequency that can only be predicted via a rigorous mathematical analysis of the complex nonlinear system. This grant also developed a universal connection graph-based method which removed a long-standing obstacle to studying synchronization in dynamical multilayer networks. This method opened up the possibility of explicitly assessing critical multilayer-induced interactions which can hamper network synchronization and revealed striking, counterintuitive effects caused by multilayer coupling. This method can be transformative in the highly active research field of synchronization in multilayer engineering and social networks, especially in regard to hidden effects not seen in single-layer networks.

Broader impacts: The grant involved four Ph.D. and two undergraduate students, including four minority students (an Afro-American, a Hispanic, and two female students). Three Ph.D.students have graduated, all with excellent job placing. Dr. Jennifer Slimowitz-Pearl, an NSF DMS program director, used this grant as an example in her outreach presentation about broader impacts at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in March 2017. It was broadcast and archived online. The research funded under this grant published in a 2017 Science Advances paper on pedestrian-bridge interactions received media coverage from major national and international news outlets, including The New York Times, Physics World, Popular Science, Science News, New Scientist, Russia News Today, and Welt Der Physik (in German). This paper generated significant interest within both the scientific community and general public. This includes dozens of private communications and overwhelming feedback received by the PI from the audience ranging from Professor Brian Josephson, a Nobel Laureate in Physics to middle school students. This work also contributed to public awarenesses about potentially faulty bridge designs; multiple private communications expressed serious concerns about and the need for dynamical testing of the stability of several bridges in the United States and beyond.  A video "Building Safer Bridge: Mathematics to the Rescue" which showcases the research funded under this grant competed in the 2019 NSF We are Mathematics Video Competition and was selected as a semi-finalist.
